reasoning:
First, I have to decide if Amazon fits inside my circle of competence. Frankly, e-commerce and cloud computing are outside the simple, predictable businesses I understand best. I’ve built my track record on soft drinks, insurance, railroads and simple consumer franchises – I know how much Coke costs to make, but I don’t really know the long-term economics of AWS or the levers behind Amazon’s razor-thin retail margins.

When it comes to moat, Amazon certainly has scale advantages and network effects, but the data show inconsistent returns on equity (only 7.7% vs. my 15% hurdle), uneven earnings growth and a hefty debt-to-equity ratio of 2.4. A durable moat gives you pricing power and consistent returns; here, the moat looks leaky at times.

On management and capital allocation, Jeff Bezos has built an empire — I admire the vision — yet owner earnings are negative, and the company hasn’t shown the kind of conservative balance sheet or clear capital-allocation philosophy I look for. No dividends, and reinvestment has yet to demonstrate reliable free cash flow to shareholders.

Financially, the picture is mixed. Operating margins are strong around 43%, but return on invested capital is a meager 2.2%, and earnings growth is erratic. My favorite gauge—owner earnings—is firmly negative. You don’t want to pay a high price for a business burning cash.

Valuation is the final nail. A three-stage DCF spits out a negative intrinsic value and a margin of safety well below zero. You know my motto: “Price is what you pay, value is what you get.” Here, the price vastly exceeds value.

Long-term prospects? Amazon will be a massive company for decades, but I’m cautious about investing in something I can’t fully value. No red flag on legality or fraud—just complexity and overvaluation.

Compare this to what sits in my portfolio – Coca-Cola, See’s Candies, Apple and GEICO – all businesses I grasp completely, generating reliable cash and trading at prices that offer real margin of safety. Amazon simply doesn’t measure up to those opportunities in my playbook.

In short, this is a quality operation in its own right, but it’s outside my wheelhouse, overly complex and priced for perfection. My answer: bearish.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 7.7%; High debt to equity ratio of 2.4; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 150.5% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Decent operating margins (avg: 47.5%) suggest some competitive advantage; High performance stability (85.2%) suggests strong competitive moat

book_value_analysis.details: Consistent book value per share growth (Buffett's favorite metric)

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (8.0%, 5y), Stage 2 (4.0%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
